Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The regulation of natural transformation in Vibrio

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The overall goal of this research is to understand the contribution of extracellular chemical signaling in the exchange of genetic material that accelerates bacterial adaptation. Although a transient human pathogen, Vibrio cholerae is an endemic marine microbe often found attached to the exoskeleton of arthropods, which are composed of the most abundant polymer in the ocean, chitin. V. cholerae is a member of a distinctive group of bacteria shown to be naturally competent to take up extracellular DNA and incorporate this genetic material onto their chromosomes. This method of horizontal gene transfer, termed natural transformation, occurs in V. cholerae in response to two environmental signaling pathways; a chitin utilization system that results in production of a regulator (TfoX), and a cell-cell communication (Quorum Sensing; QS) system that induces production of the transcription factor (HapR). The genes and network connections that link TfoX and HapR to DNA uptake are not known. Thus, this project will address the following aims. Aim 1: To identify genes that participate in horizontal gene transfer in response to extracellular QS signal molecules and to chitin. Aim 2: To define regulatory pathways connecting QS and chitin signaling to natural transformation. Aim 3: To examine the function of natural transformation network components. Aim 4: To determine the functionality of QS- and chitin-induced pathways in diverse V. cholerae environmental isolates. The research in this proposal is designed to exploit our understanding of chitin utilization and the V. cholerae QS paradigm for the identification of novel natural transformation genes. This research will dissect the role that both habitat and genetics play in bacterial evolution.

Broader Impacts: The applicant engages in teaching and service to integrate individuals in the academic community with members of the broader society in the process of modern scientific inquiry. Dr. Hammer teaches a Prokaryotic Molecular Genetics course for upper-level undergraduates and graduate students; and has established research collaborations with colleagues within the Unites States and other countries, to promote scientific and cultural exchange opportunities for his lab members. He initiated a substantial outreach program in 2009 that is expanded here, hosting a fifth grade teacher to work as a summer intern in his lab. Together Dr. Hammer and the teacher develop stimulating hands-on scientific exercises that engage ethnically diverse K-12 students in metro Atlanta. Activities are shared with local educators and will be presented at regional or national meetings including the National Science Teachers Association conference. Dr. Hammer is also an active teacher and mentor for students at all levels and post-doctoral fellows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Bacteria are the dominant form of life on Earth. These tiny microbes work together to provide essential services for us and our planet, such as cycling of nutrients, producing oxygen, and digesting the food in our intestines. Several are also notorious for causing diseases in plants and animals, including humans. The PIs goal is to understand how these bacteria interact with one another to accomplish such tasks. His NSF-supported research shows ways that bacteria both cooperate and compete with one another in the dense communities where they reside. Like all living organisms, bacteria carry DNA that codes for the functions they accomplish. Many bacteria can share this genetic material with one another, such as the DNA that allows certain disease-causing microbes to be resistant to antibiotics. One form of genetic exchange is called “natural transformation” because the DNA shared by the donor changes the capabilities of the recipient. A special apparatus made on the recipient's surface allows it to take up foreign DNA and put then it onto its chromosome. The research performed here identified specific conditions that are required to trigger the production of the DNA uptake machinery. The research also led to additional insights. Specifically, the PI showed that the conditions that lead to genetic exchange also signal bacteria to produce a harpoon-like weapon for puncturing and killing adjacent neighbors, which can restructure the organization of cells in bacterial communities. The PI also showed that intestinal bacteria in a host can also use the weaponry to interact directly with cells of the host and alter how the intestine functions. Since many of the bacteria that live in our intestinal tracts use similar tactics to compete with their neighbors, this research may lead to the development of novel probiotics that repurpose the weaponry to engineer healthy gut communities.

 

Broader Impacts: The PI teaches two lectures courses, one undergraduate biology course for non-majors, and another molecular microbiology course for upper-level undergraduates and graduate students. As chair of the undergraduate curriculum committee, he has participated in the development and implementation of initiatives such as a new Neuroscience major and a Health and Medical Sciences minor to better prepare students for life science careers. He serves at faculty advisor for his campus chapter of the American Society for Microbiology. Regarding community and lay-person outreach, he hosted several K-12 teachers in his laboratory for summer internships and visits local schools to provide hands-on activities for students and teachers in Metro Atlanta. The PI has presented for Story Collider and TEDx. He is currently a Distinguished Lecturer for the American Society for Microbiology, where he interacts directly with students, postdocs, and other early career scientists and lectures at local branch meetings of the society. Most importantly, he is an active mentor to a diverse group of young researchers in his laboratory.
